newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania offers tax exemption for cars.
newsitem.headline: Romania offers tax exemption for cars.

text.p: Romania has issued a quota worth $5 million to import tax-exempt cars until the end of the year, trade ministry officials said on Tuesday.

"We thought this would diversify the range of cars and bring more affordable automobiles to Romanians," Sorin Popescu, director of the trade ministry's licences and trade policy department said by telephone.
Under the move, some 20 unspecified companies obtained licences to import catalyser-equipped petrol or diesel cars with a capacity of up to 3,000 cubic centimetres, he said.
Popescu said the accord would cover some 400 cars imported free of a 30 percent import duty, or 24 percent for automobiles produced by European Union countries.

The Romanian local market is split between the old-fashioned Dacia, produced by the state-owned carmaker Automobile Dacia SA and the substantially more expensive Cielo made by South Korea's Daewoo Heavy Industries -- a big seller from 1995.
The South Korean carmaker has bought a controlling stake in another Romanian state-owned carmaker Automobile Craiova and plans to make 75,000 cars a year, or half the local market.
A Dacia car, an obsolete variant of the old Renault 12, costs around 17 million lei. ($=3,311 lei)
